#5 {main} thrown in /home/public_html/phpSmug/phpSmug.php on line 1464

I am trying to upload 100 images each of size 3 MB,  When a page is loading, the authentication occurs with the API and upload 10 images at  a time. then there is meta refresh tag added at the bottom of the page to reload for processing the next 10 images. Please advise me what did i wrong here?

title: Fix conditional exports in package
body:
This fixes an error I encountered in a dependent package ([`pmndrs/leva`](https://github.com/pmndrs/leva)) while building it with a barebones `esbuild` config. According to the NodeJS docs, only `"import",` `"require"`, `"node"` and `"default"` are valid keys, `"module"` is not:

https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#packages_conditional_exports

(Not sure if `"types"` are considered by TS or not, so I left those in. Also shout-outs to @n1ru4l who correctly identified this problem ðŸ¥‡ )

title: import `overwrite-globals` not working

I need to apply the global polyfill as we load a js file seperately on older browsers to reduce unnecessary code.

The [docs here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/clipboard-polyfill#overwrite-globals-version) mention `import 'clipboard-polyfill/overwrite-globals';` to do it, but it's not resolving this:

Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'clipboard-polyfill/overwrite-globals'

Is there something I'm missing?

Thanks in advance for any help!

title: Firefox doesn't support readText
body:
Hi, thank for the great library!

I'm using Firefox (75) and the "paste" function doesn't work:

![Screenshot from 2020-05-02 14-18-22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5953369/80857902-cf9b0600-8c7f-11ea-9113-bed18607a962.png)

I'm not sure if this is the expected behavior and I should handle it myself. Afaik it's because Firefox does have the `navigator.clipboard` object but in non-extension context it only has writeText but no readText:

![Screenshot from 2020-05-02 14-15-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5953369/80857923-f9ecc380-8c7f-11ea-9b2d-275ab83c6575.png)

Ref: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/readText#Browser_compatibility

> Notes Firefox only supports reading the clipboard in browser extensions, using the "clipboardRead" extension permission.

Do you think clipboard-polyfill should fallback to another mechanism to handle the read in Firefox? Like what you did with IE

Thank you

title: Fixed infinite recursion bug
body:
Attempting to assign the imported module to `navigator.clipboard` and then using the `writeText` or `readText` methods would recurse infinitely, resulting in a stack overflow.

The reason for this was the faulty attempt to read from `navigator.clipboard` if it's available, regardless of what that binding actually references.

This commit forbids the use of `navigator.clipboard` if it contains a reference to the polyfill itself.

title: Does not work in Firefox 72.0.2/Linux64
body:
Hi

I have the following in the `head` section of my HTML page:
`<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/clipboard-polyfill/2.8.6/clipboard-polyfill.js"></script>`

But it behaves exactly the same way as without this line when I'm trying to `clipboard.writeText('something')`: throwing undefined as result of promise returned by `writeText`.


p.s.
Occasionally, i also have Chromium with the following version: Version 79.0.3945.130 (Developer Build) built on Debian 10.2, running on Debian 10.2 (64-bit)
And in Chromium clipboard operation works just fine, as specified. No polyfill required to solve anything there. But I noticed that this library makes `clipboard` object available from `window` object. Without it `clipboard` object is accessible only through `navigator.clipboard`. Not sure if it's an issue, but MDN says that `navigator.clipboard` is the standard way to go.

Bump handlebars from 4.1.2 to 4.5.3
body:
Bumps [handlebars](https://github.com/wycats/handlebars.js) from 4.1.2 to 4.5.3.
Changelog *Sourced from [handlebars's changelog](https://github.com/wycats/handlebars.js/blob/master/release-notes.md).* > ## v4.5.3 - November 18th, 2019 > Bugfixes: > > - fix: add "no-prototype-builtins" eslint-rule and fix all occurences - f7f05d7 > - fix: add more properties required to be enumerable - 1988878 > > Chores / Build: > - fix: use !== 0 instead of != 0 - c02b05f > - add chai and dirty-chai and sinon, for cleaner test-assertions and spies, > deprecate old assertion-methods - 93e284e, 886ba86, 0817dad, 93516a0 > > Security: > > - The properties `__proto__`, `__defineGetter__`, `__defineSetter__` and `__lookupGetter__` > have been added to the list of "properties that must be enumerable". > If a property by that name is found and not enumerable on its parent, > it will silently evaluate to `undefined`. This is done in both the compiled template and the "lookup"-helper. > This will prevent new Remote-Code-Execution exploits that have been > published recently. > > Compatibility notes: > > - Due to the security-fixes. The semantics of the templates using > `__proto__`, `__defineGetter__`, `__defineSetter__` and `__lookupGetter__` in the respect that those expression now return > `undefined` rather than their actual value from the proto. > - The semantics have not changed in cases where the properties are enumerable, as in: > > ```js > { > __proto__: 'some string' > } > ``` > > - The change may be breaking in that respect, but we still only > increase the patch-version, because the incompatible use-cases > are not intended, undocumented and far less important than fixing > Remote-Code-Execution exploits on existing systems. > > > > [Commits](https://github.com/wycats/handlebars.js/compare/v4.5.2...v4.5.3) > > ## v4.5.2 - November 13th, 2019 > # Bugfixes > > - fix: use String(field) in lookup when checking for "constructor" - d541378 > - test: add fluent API for testing Handlebars - c2ac79c > > Compatibility notes: > - no incompatibility are to be expected > ... (truncated)

Hi!

Your polyfill is great!
I really liked your early implementation of `read` and `write` using `DataTransfer` and I know that this is even mentioned in the Explainer (https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/blob/master/explainer.adoc#writing-to-the-clipboard) but the current implementation of Chrome is now using `Array<ClipboardItem>` objects as you can see here (https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2019/07/image-support-for-async-clipboard#images).

Stefan

title: iOS Safari copying empty string
body:
This is a follow-up to https://github.com/lgarron/clipboard-polyfill/issues/42#issuecomment-497145354

When we pass a text string to `writeText`, it works on every platform/browser except iOS, where it instead copies an empty string (it doesn't just fail to copy, it actually writes an empty string to the clipboard).

I don't have a simple repro to give you, but I debugged this together with a couple of Apple's WebKit engineers at WWDC and wanted to share observations.

The issue occurs in the "Fallback 1 for desktop Safari" branch, where it calls `copyUsingTempSelection`. At that point it "successfully" copies the empty string, so the code never reaches the branch labeled "Fallback for iOS Safari." If we removed the `copyUsingTempSelection` branch so that it _does_ reach "Fallback for iOS Safari," _that does work_.

I will note that the WebKit devs were pretty confused by `copyUsingTempSelection`, both by what it's trying to do and why it's considered necessary for desktop Safari.

title: Copy not working for Opera Mobile
body:
Copying and pasting is not working for mobile clients, like:
* Opera Mini
* Opera Touch
* Opera for Android

Thrown exception: `NotAllowedError: Write/Read permission denied`

I think this problem is permissions, which are not supported in Opera clients.
All Opera clients are based on Chromium, but it seems that Chrome is handling those in some other way (probably has own implementation for permissions).

I've tested it on https://garron.net/code/clipboard-polyfill/
What works for Opera Mobile:
* Markup
* DOM node

What doesn't work:
* Plain Text
* Paste Text

As Opera has a quite nice usage on Mobile Phones I think it's worth to consider to add library-support for it.
Not working real page with a lot of users, for example:
https://hsreplay.net/decks/zBIJy80UbyGGAPvK2OAhsd/ -> Copy deck to hearthstone

Thanks!
Przemek

title: Change from the default export to the full export object
body:
As of v2.7.0, the intended way to use `clipboard-polyfill` will be:

    import * as clipboard from "clipboard-polyfill"
    // ...
    clipboard.writeText("hi!")

Or:

    const clipboard = require("clipboard-polyfill")

This replaces the old convention of the `default` export:

    // Old â€“ do not use unless your environment requires it
    import clipboard from "clipboard-polyfill"

In some environments, `import *` worked previously. However, I believe this change will be compatible with more environments/build systems. Hopefully that will address #77.

If you use the `default` export, then there is a compatibility shim will still work in `v2.7.0` but will print a warning. I plan to drop support for the `default` export in `v3.0.0`. Please comment here if you believe this will introduce an incompatibility for you, ideally with a link to a repo with a full repro case.

title: Improve imports
body:
`import clipboard from 'clipboard-polyfill'` is not always compatible with newer projects that have to use an import statement like `import * as clipboard from 'clipboard-polyfill'` or 
`import { clipboard } from clipboard-polyfill`.

title: Amend Function and eval Constructor
body:
**Amend `eval` and the `Function` constructor to typeof window == 'undefined' ? typeof global == 'undefined' ? this : global : window**

It's easier to see the changes if you use Atom beautify package (or equivalent) to unminify the code. Lines changed are 406 and 606

Amending due to Issue with uploading to Firefox Add on store and followed advice here https://github.com/YuzuJS/setImmediate/issues/49

title: Amend `eval` and the `Function` constructor to typeof window == 'undefined' ? typeof global == 'undefined' ? this : global : window
body:
When using the clipboard-polyfill.js in a firefox extension and submitting it to https://addons.mozilla.org, the extension Validation Results produced warnings:

> Warning: Evaluation of strings as code can lead to security vulnerabilities and performance issues, even in the most innocuous of circumstances. Please avoid using `eval` and the `Function` constructor when at all possible.'
> js/clipboard-polyfill.js line 406
> js/clipboard-polyfill.js line 606

As suggested in this github page: https://github.com/YuzuJS/setImmediate/issues/49

I amended these lines to use the below code instead, which solved the validation issue with the code.
`typeof window == 'undefined' ? typeof global == 'undefined' ? this : global : window`

I propose amending line 406 from:
`            t = Function("return this")()
`
to
`            t = typeof window == 'undefined' ? typeof global == 'undefined' ? this : global : window
`

...and 606 from
     ` n = n || Function("return this")() || (0, eval)("this")`
to:
      `n = n || typeof window == 'undefined' ? typeof global == 'undefined' ? this : global : window`

title: Edge <17 doesn't write out proper CF_HTML
body: FYI on a compatibility issue... Calling `clipboardData.setData("text/html", data)` writes the `data` argument verbatim in Edge 16.16299 and earlier. That means your "DOM node" test results in the clipboard containing this (according to a low-level clipboard inspector): ``` This will be copied. ``` which isn't valid [CF_HTML](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms649015(v=vs.85).aspx). Chrome does it correctly: ``` Version:0.9 StartHTML:0000000105 EndHTML:0000000416 StartFragment:0000000141 EndFragment:0000000380 This will be copied. ``` as does FF: ``` Version:0.9 StartHTML:00000097 EndHTML:00000406 StartFragment:00000131 EndFragment:00000370 This will be copied. ``` FWIW, I think these are the relevant bits of FF's and Chrome's source that writes the CF_HTML format: https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/widget/windows/nsDataObj.cpp#1927, https://cs.chromium.org/chromium/src/ui/base/clipboard/clipboard_util_win.cc?q=StartFragment&sq=package:chromium&dr=C&l=380. It looks like this will be fixed in Edge 17, https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/14372529/, so maybe a wontfix here. (Cool library btw!)

title: Doesn't work in IE<11 due to use of Set API
body: https://github.com/lgarron/clipboard-polyfill/blob/be05dad095f68fb32df1b4f5927c3827c86dfd25/DT.ts#L6 `Set` first appears in IE11, so execution in an older version of IE errors out when it hits this line.

${recipe.instructions}

title: More nuances to clipboard handling.
body:
These were tested on Windows 10.  Just thought I'd share some of my observations.  There is way too much nuance to getting data to the clipboard with the existing, broken APIs.  Thank you for documenting so many of the details!  I wish I'd found your polyfill before finding similar solutions.

1. Chrome crashes with an "aw snap" if you try to call e.clipboard.setData("text/plain", data) with data.length > 60MB.  Firefox/Edge don't crash.

2. Chrome/FF/Edge have a watchdog timer.  I've measured this at a 1s on Chrome.  Formatting 6MB of ascii text (from an SVG) takes around 30s.  So if you generate an export, pass the string to a hidden textArea, and then select() that.  Ignoring the time to export (which can be many seconds) leaves you with an always failed execCommand('copy') afterwards.

You have to perform the export and setData() calls within the 'copy' listener.  Then the watchdog timer doesn't seem to apply.  So run execCommand as quickly as possible, then take your time.

3. Formatting a hidden text area with 100MB takes around 100s.  This freezes up the browser while this happens, and users think the web app has crashed. 

There doesn't seem to be a way to:
  a. can't provide progress 
      the export and setData have to occur in the listener, 
      anything else gets killed by the watchdog timer
  b. can't use setTimeout (or it's no longer user-initiated)
  c. can't defer evaluation of clipboard data until client paste
     (key to apps on OSX/Windows/Linux)
 
We've reported these on the new clipboard API spec that you are emulating with this polyfill.

title: setTimeout cann't copy text
Always pastes text/plain content, never text/html
body: I have tested it in Chrome 62 and IE11, if I ever set a text/plain then I will never get the markup/html version. However, if I only set the text/html, it will work correctly from both, other than not being able to paste into plain text fields. Not sure what is supposed to happen, but I think its not correct behavior that it is falling back every time, even though the html can work. Nice work though :)

title: Expand set of data types
body: https://w3c.github.io/clipboard-apis/#writing-to-clipboard

title: How to make copy works inside an ajax callback
body:
Hi,
i need to copy the text returned from an AJAX request that fire when a button is clicked.
The problem is that inside the click event listener I call the function that perform the AJAX request but the returned data are processed inside a callback function (ajax success) that is no more inside the original click event listener, thus the copy fails.
The only walk around that make copy works is to make the ajax call synchronous (async: false jQuery option).
I'm wondering if there is another way to make copy works in my scenario that keep AJAX async (as it should be).  
Thank you.

title: Copy clip not working first run for async load clipboard.js
Migrate dependent projects from legacy API functions
Type definition
body: Addresses #61. Type declaration files will now be generated during `make` and users of the module will no longer need a separately maintained `@types` package.

title: Type definition
body:
I was about to file a report with DefinitelyTyped about creating a @types/clipboard-polyfill based on @types/clipboard-js, but since this is now already in TypeScript, it looks like that shouldn't even be necessary!

You can achieve the same thing here with `tsc --declaration clipboard-polyfill.ts` and adding `"types": "./clipboard-polyfill.d.ts"` to package.json, which printed a few errors (copied below) but otherwise seems to work as expected.

```
DT.ts(7,40): error TS2693: 'Map' only refers to a type, but is being used as a value here.
DT.ts(10,26): error TS2339: Property 'has' does not exist on type 'Set<string>'.

DT.ts(23,19): error TS2339: Property 'forEach' does not exist on type 'Map<string, string>'.

```

title: Convenience method to intercept user copy.
body:
Maybe something like:

  interceptCopy(callback: () => null|ClipboardPolyfill.DT)

The callback would specify whether the to overwrite the data on the clipboard event, and with what.
Ideally, we would pass a parameter to the callback to tell them if the event was user-initiated, but I don't think there's a nice way to do this without e.g. swizzling `document.execCommand` (Fields like `event.isTrusted` don't help.)

Should the callback be synchronous?

- A synchronous callback allows us to modify `event.clipboardData` in the event listener itself.
- A synchronous event listener does not allow the callback to make asynchronous calculations.
- In some browsers, synchronous modification of `event.clipboardData` may be buggy.
- In some browsers, we may be able to trigger `document.execCommand()` an additional time, either inside the initial handler, or using `setTimeout()`. This may be buggy in different situations.

Requested by @thomasjm

title: Expose feature detection.
body:
See issues #23 and #25. Where possible, it would be nice to detect ahead of time which of the following will work, and expose an API to query it. In response, a developer could e.g. use a Flash fallback only when necessary.
- Plain text copying
- Rich text copying
- Pasting

Since a successful copy/paste has a user-visible side effect, it would be nice to avoid triggering them unless you actually want to perform the action.

(However, on OSX, the OS converts the rich text to simple text if you're not pasting into a rich text context.)

In order to work in IE, we'd have to strip tags and convert to a string first. I don't know if there's a good cross-browser way to strip tags (is there anything related to `XMLSerializer`?).

title: Race condition in `clipboard.paste()`
body:
The `"paste"` event listener depends on `_interceptPaste` to hold it its value. If the user is somehow able to trigger a paste event that fires between `clipboard.paste()` and the synthetic `"paste"`, then it will be intercepted incorrectly.
This isn't supposed to be possible, because `document.execCommand()` is synchronous. But I feel like we should have something more robust.

It would be nice if we could tell directly tell whether the `"paste"` event is synthetic (from the Javascript event).

title: License Consistency
body:
I am currently working on a brew formula for folderify found [here](https://github.com/harens/homebrew-folderify).

When I audit it (in the hopes of adding it to [homebrew/core](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core)), I get the following error:

```shell
* License mismatch - GitHub license is: [], but Formulae license states: ["MIT"].
```

I had set the license to MIT since this is what is stated on the [PyPi project description](https://pypi.org/project/folderify/). If I don't set a license, the audit also complains.

```shell
* No license specified for package.
```

title: Remove 'ie-compatibility-mode.html'

title: Lower case to match style guide
body:
This makes the code snippet match the actual best practice that this site is actually using.

Also, I am inserting a preference for lower case utf-8, preferred over UTF-8, because lower case letters compress better than upper case letters.

This different is negligible, perhaps one or two bits on every HTML document ever. But removing a seemingly equivalent option ("UTF-8") from consideration is priceless.

title: add webComponent specific attribute to Attribute Order
body:
I think the following should be added to the `Attribute Order` since webcomponent are more and more used.  (I'm working with angular, but would make sense for any other framework)
```html
    <custom-component
      [type]="myType"
      [ngSwitch]="condition"
      (myEvent)="onMyEvent()"
      *ngIf="enabled"
    ></custom-component>
```
_I would put those after the `data-*` one (`'data-.+', 'ng-.+', '[.+', '(.+', '*ng+',`)_

title: The HTML5 standard does not require quotes around attribute values.
body:
Code Guide reads: > Always use double quotes, never single quotes, on attributes. However, HTML5 standards say that attributes can be written even without quotes, but it should be mentioned that they are recommended because of stricter languages like XHTML demand quotes. Sometimes it is necessary to use quotes. This example will not display the title attribute correctly, because it contains a space: ``

`` Double quotes around attribute values are the most common in HTML, but single quotes can also be used. In some situations, when the attribute value itself contains double quotes, it is necessary to use single quotes: ``

`` Or vice versa: ``

``

title: Add hyperlinks for Sass and Less
Advice on JavaScript generated markup offers no solution
body:
The section "JavaScript generated markup" simple states "Writing markup in a JavaScript file makes the content harder to find, harder to edit, and less performant. Avoid it whenever possible.".

It tells you what not to do.
But it offers no solution or advice on alternatives.

Perhaps the [`template`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/template) element is a viable alternative?

title: Grouping & ordering Bootstrap classes
body:
Thanks for creating this styleguide! I'm working on a design system, and having these rules will keep it clean and consistent.

You've specified an [order of attributes](http://codeguide.co/#html-attribute-order) for HTML and a [declaration order](http://codeguide.co/#css-declaration-order) for CSS , but I can't find a recommended order for classes, here or elsewhere on the net. 

I'm trying to use Bootstrap classes wherever possible, instead of writing my own CSS, and it's getting unwieldy in some places. For example:

```html
<div class="container navbar navbar-light bg-light navbar-expand-md flex-wrap align-items-start">
  <div class="collapse navbar-collapse justify-content-end flex-wrap order-5" id="navbarNav">
```

Obviously, we can't make rules for every single class! But I'm curious: **do you have any guidelines for grouping and ordering layout/component/utility classes, especially within Bootstrap 4?**

title: Removed Spanish because content is not available
Why necessarily specifying optional closing tags?
body: Hi, The Code Guide reads: > Donâ€™t omit optional closing tags (e.g. or ). I think it would be good to either give a very good reason or otherwise remove this statement. The HTML 5.1 (and probably the previous ones) explicitly say the closing tags are not necessary in certain precise circumstances, and even give examples of HTML code where the implicit closings tags are not written. I am not aware of them recommending against this practice, it rather looks like they are encouraging it since they do omit them in some code examples (although some other code snippets of the specification do not omit optional closing tags). Besides, this makes the code lighter and much easier to read. Just compare the two: ``` â€¦ Price in 2017 78,50 79,50 82,50 86,00 107,50 87,00 100,00 90,50 90,50 82,00 88,00 99,00 â€¦ ``` With the closing tags: ``` â€¦ Price in 2017 78,50 79,50 82,50 86,00 107,50 87,00 100,00 90,50 90,50 82,00 88,00 99,00 â€¦ ``` Now I know that I am not obliged to put the content of the `td` elements on a new line, but if I had HTML elements nested inside `td` elements (which I do on several of my projects), I would have to anyway. When working on complex HTML structures such as this one (I am working on documents with several HTML tables spanning about 300 lines each without the use of ending tags), not omitting them would be both inefficient and unreadable, while not using them would be completely valid.

title: Correct 'lang' attribute in html tag
body:
I replaced `lang="en-us"` with `lang="en"` in `html` tag. A few reasons:

- This code-guide links to [a list of language codes](https://www.sitepoint.com/web-foundations/iso-2-letter-language-codes/) for the `lang` attributes which contains `EN` for American English.
- An example in [the specification](http://w3c.github.io/html/semantics.html#the-html-element) uses `lang="en"`
- GitHub.com uses `lang="en"`, too.

title: Box-model and border
body:
Helloâ€¦

The declaration order says [â€œBox-modelâ€ comes first](https://github.com/mdo/code-guide/blob/dabd68d00bd8f10f588c3aec986a7c8776f68831/_includes/css/declaration-order.css#L10), and [â€œVisualâ€ later on](https://github.com/mdo/code-guide/blob/dabd68d00bd8f10f588c3aec986a7c8776f68831/_includes/css/declaration-order.css#L22). This is cool. Nothing to say on the sorting.

What surprises me is to find `border` in the â€œVisualâ€ section, when it is part of the box-model.

Iâ€™m surprised I couldnâ€™t find an issue about this, which means I might have missed a discussion somewhere. Feel free to link and close if thatâ€™s the case. :)

title: Combining media queries
body: I agree that it is nice to have the media queries "as close to their relevant rule sets whenever possible". This generates a bunch of extra code that can't be minimized by just compilation or minification. Thoughts on mentioning a tool like [node-combine-mq](https://github.com/frontendfriends/node-combine-mq) to combine them into matching media queries? This would compliment the notion of having them close to their relevance while also the benefits of combining them.

title: Swap aria-*, role in Attribute order section
body: `role` should be defined first, followed by an `aria-*` property since a lot of ARIA roles expect certain properties to be used in conjunction with. For example, ``` html ``` makes perfect sense, rather than to have the attributes the other way around.

title: Better language code reference
body:
On sitepoint's ISO 2 Letter Language Codes (linked on html-lang section), language code for Indonesian are IN, but HTML validator said to use ID instead as IN are deprecated.

Here's registry from https://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry/language-subtag-registry

```
Type: language
Subtag: in
Description: Indonesian
Added: 2005-10-16
Deprecated: 1989-01-01
Preferred-Value: id
Suppress-Script: Latn
Macrolanguage: ms
```

scrot from https://r12a.github.io/apps/subtags/

title: Misleading statement
body:
"Every line of code should appear to be written by a single person, no matter the number of contributors."

I think this is meant to say that the whole HTML document (or all documents?) should appear written by the same person, however it implies that only each individual line should appear written by the same person.

I.e. each line could have a different standard, but as long as each line appears written by the same person it's ok.

I'd suggest changing it to something like this: 

"Every line of code in your HTML documents should appear to be written by the same person, no matter the number of contributors."

title: Generic element tag selectors also bad for reasons besides perf
body:
The current guidance in the Guide is:

> - Use classes over generic element tag for optimum rendering performance.

But there are non-perf-related reasons to avoid them too, right? Like why we're trying to avoid them in Bootstrap going forward?
e.g. They're unnecessarily constraining in some cases. Maybe my component uses an `h2` today, but tomorrow I might want it to use an `h4` instead, so it's annoying if the component's CSS relies on this aspect of the DOM.

title: IE compatibility mode specifics
body:
Love this project, thank you.

A note about the 'IE compatibility mode' section. It's a great idea to include it, however, in order for this tag to work as you expect, it needs to come before all other elements in the `<head>` excluding the `<title>` and other `<meta>` elements.  Unfortunately, the location of the tag totally changes the behavior.

> "The X-UA-Compatible header isn't case sensitive; however, it must appear in the header of the webpage (the HEAD section) before all other elements except for the title element and other meta elements."
> â€” [MSDN Specifying legacy document modes](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/jj676915.aspx)

There's a mention of this in the comments of the Stack Overflow article linked in your description but it's pretty buried. Seems like information that could be good to present up front. Let me know what you think. I could add a pull request with a change if you think it's useful here.

title: double vs single quotes
body:
What is the motivation for single vs double quotes?

It is often desirable to switch between the two as per convenience. For example in PHP it is better to write (1) `echo "<a href='$href'>";` as opposed to (2) `"echo <a href=\"$href\">";`.

HTML and for that matter most other languages allow for single versus double quotes for this reason.

title: Add lang attribute to html tag as recommendation
body:
From [html tag section](http://www.w3.org/html/wg/drafts/html/master/semantics.html#the-html-element) in W3C HTML5 Editor's draft:

> Authors are encouraged to specify a lang attribute on the root html element, giving the document's language. This aids speech synthesis tools to determine what pronunciations to use, translation tools to determine what rules to use, and so forth.

So IMHO would be nice to have a recommendation to use `lang` attribute into `<html>` tag.

title: CSS nomenclature
body:
This is an early PR to gather some feedback on what else folks would like to see in the Code Guide. I often run into problems when describing the content of a CSS file and until a couple years ago I didn't know most of these terms by heart either. Documenting the most common ones with examples seems like a good idea, but it's a lot of new content.

Here's how it looks currently with just a few items stubbed out:

![Nomenclature](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/98681/2338786/767c46b2-a4ad-11e3-87f3-dcd4108c579b.png)

Some things I'd like feedback on:
- Should nomenclature be it's own section, split from the main HTML and CSS ones? Perhaps as a glossary?
- What level of detail is too much? Should we do into every type of selector?
- Is there another format that would serve this better?

<3

title: Attribute order - id first
body:
Maybe there is sense to use the id attribute first?
In this order:
- id
- class
- data-*
- src, for, type, href

Arguments:
1. Using id attribute is less than using classes but often more important for the application logic
2. String of classes can be very long and we may miss the id attribute

Example from http://getbootstrap.com/
`<header class="navbar navbar-static-top bs-docs-nav" id="top" role="banner">`
I prefer:
`<header id="top" class="navbar navbar-static-top bs-docs-nav" role="banner">`

title: Update and rename LICENSE.md to LICENSE
Add support for progressive enhancement
body: Currently, the buttons are loaded in iframes no matter what browser and settings are used. When JavaScript is disabled, the buttons don't work at all. I think that adding progressive enhancement would be a good idea. The code would consist of two parts: * A link e.g. `Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub` * A script e.g. `` And here is how the progressive enhancement would work: * If JavaScript is disabled in your browser, the link would be used as a fallback. * If JavaScript is enabled in your browser, the script will first detect if your browser supports shadow DOM. Shadow DOM is a replacement for iframes that is faster than iframes. * If the browser you're using doesn't support shadow DOM, then all links with the `.gh-button` class would be read by the script and replaced with iframes. * If the browser you're using supports shadow DOM, than all links with the `.gh-button` class would be read by the script and replaced with shadow DOMs. So basically the progressive enhancement is from links to iframes to shadow DOMs.

title: Link to fork count does not point to members

title: Star count no longer showing on one of my GitHub buttons
body:
Thank you for creating and open sourcing github-buttons! We've used them on our website for 2+ years now.

We recently noticed that one of our buttons no longer displays the star count; however, the second button is working just fine.

Here are links to the buttons:
working: https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=async-labs&repo=saas&type=star&count=true&size=large
not working: https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=builderbook&repo=builderbook&type=star&count=true&size=large

Do you know what the problem could be?

title: Add jekyll-seo-tag and robots.txt
Add CodeQL Analysis workflow
body:
Adds a GitHub Actions workflow that runs CodeQL on every push, and on a daily schedule.

Code scanning looks for vulnerabilities, such as XSS, SQL injection, etc., in your code. If it finds any new vulnerabilities it surfaces them in the PR as check annotations, and blocks the build until theyâ€™re fixed or marked as false positives. If it finds any on the repoâ€™s default branch it displays them in the [security tab](../security/code-scanning).

For now you also need to be feature flagged individually to see results in the security tab (as well as having write permission on this repo) - if you drop an email to jhutchings1@github.com I can get anyone you need added. 

Finally, this is an early access program that has not been released yet, so please don't share before May 6th when weâ€™re unveiling it at GitHub Satellite.

Cc: @greysteil

title: Add queries checks
body:
Currently there are no checks for queries.

We basically need either `user` and `type=sponsor` or `user` and `repo` and `type`.

title: Add icon-only variant
body: Wonder if it'd make sense to do an icon-only version where there is no button text?

title: Improve Cloudflare's caching
body:
Right now we don't make full use of Cloudflare's caching. HTML files are not cached by default.

We should look into these:

1. Cache everything; it should be fine since the code does not change frequently and we can always purge the cache when we release a new version. The default cache is 4 hours but we can change it to something else
2. Maybe look into ignoring the query strings and cache the file the same? Query strings do not affect the served HTML, only the GitHub API request

I plan to look into the above one thing at a time, in case we break something.

title: iframes should have accessible names
body: Google's [Lighthouse](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse) is flagging for accessibility issues when [iframe is missing the `title` attribute](https://web.dev/frame-title/) and consequently lowers the website's score. Consider adding appropriate titles such as `title="Star on Github"` to iframes in the documentation. âœŒï¸

title: V4 dev
body:
I think we could probably safely cherrypick some of the patches for v4, but if not we can cut another release later.

This branch is based on my v4 branch, which has some extra fixes compared to the upstream v4 branch, so the diff is this:

https://github.com/XhmikosR/github-buttons/compare/v4...v4-dev?w=1

Preview: <https://tender-mestorf-c6af77.netlify.com/>

title: Prepping v4
body:
Cherry-picking changes from other PRs, plus planning to add more of my own updates. Been a while since I touched this codebase, so hoping to go slow and ensure I don't break anything.

---

Highlights:

- **NEW**: Added sponsor button (pass `type=sponsor`)
- **NEW**: Updated the font stack to a more modern one
- **BREAKING**: Dropped ancient CSS vendor prefixes and IE < 10 support; the button will still work on IE9, but it won't look perfect, IE < 9 no longer works.
- **ENHANCEMENT**: Reduced filesize: approximately **-20%** off the uncompressed github-btn.html's size (6849 -> 5419 bytes)
- **ENHANCEMENT**: When `count=true` is not passed, we now don't make any GitHub API request which should significantly improve page load times

---

- Improved button's accessibility:
  - counter is hidden with `aria-hidden` if it's empty
  - a title is added in the `iframe`
- Improve button's HTML
  - add `doctype`
  - add `lang`
  - add `charset`
  - add `rel="noopener noreferrer"` for external links
  - remove `aria-label` since we set it via JS
- Improve button's CSS:
  - the embedded SVG is no longer base64-encoded (-45% off the uncompressed SVG)
  - the embedded SVG is optimized with SVGO (approximately -25% off the compressed SVG, -28% off the uncompressed SVG)
  - the CSS is streamlined
- Improved button's JS:
  - we no longer make unneeded GitHub API calls, for example if you don't pass `query=true`
  - add a few fail-safe checks
  - switched to `Node.textContent` since we weren't adding HTML
  - wrap the code in an IIFE so that the minifier mangles the variables properly
  - switch to strict mode
- Build:
  - it should be generally easier to work on the project locally; `npm i && bundle i` to get started
  - replace gulp with npm scripts
  - add CSS/Sass linting with Stylelint
  - and JS linting with xo
  - add a watch script
  - update Jekyll to v4.0.0
  - add CI for tests and docs deployments
- Docs:
  - the docs are HTML5 valid
  - the docs are WCAG2AA valid
  - add `link rel=canonical`
  - add `meta generator` tag
  - switch to Sass
  - inline the docs CSS

TODO:

- [x] Update Sponsors URL
- [x] Replace follower count with sponsors count, if possible, or drop the count
- [x] Update colors and fonts to match latest of GitHub
- [x] Adjust docs a bit to incorporate the above
- [x] Mention more of the changes in the changelog above and remove references to PRs since most of the patches have changed since the PRs
- [x] Adapt docs iframes width (check macOS)
- [x] Reduce docs sponsor iframes width
- [x] Fix ToC tap targets being too close (maybe adding padding/margin should do it)
- [x] Add a `PERSONAL_TOKEN` secret in the repo for deployments to work

Fixes #130, fixes #137, closes #115

Links:
- https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/language-of-page.html
- https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/3.2/html-has-lang?application=msftAI

Code path:
```
<html>
```

Downstream issue, https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-docs/issues/2617

title: Error: The frameborder attribute on the iframe element is obsolete. Use CSS instead.
body:
When I validate my website using the W3C validation service (https://validator.w3.org/) it prints the following errors:

```
Error: The frameborder attribute on the iframe element is obsolete. Use CSS instead.
From line 91, column 11; to line 91, column 193
<iframe src="https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=kimwalisch&repo=primesieve&type=watch&count=true&size=large" frameborder="0" scrolling="0" style="width:170px; height: 30px;"></iframe>â†©

Error: The scrolling attribute on the iframe element is obsolete. Use CSS instead.
From line 91, column 11; to line 91, column 193
<iframe src="https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=kimwalisch&repo=primesieve&type=watch&count=true&size=large" frameborder="0" scrolling="0" style="width:170px; height: 30px;"></iframe>â†©
```

It seems like ```frameborder``` and ```scrolling``` have been obsoleted in HTML5.

Hi there fellow Hubber. If you're seeing this, that means that your site's custom domain is [pointed to a deprecated IP](https://github.com/blog/1917-github-pages-legacy-ip-deprecation). :-1:

The good news is that it's an easy fix. Simply follow [these instructions](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-up-a-custom-domain-with-github-pages/) for updating your site's DNS records. :+1:

:heart: and automation,
â€” The @github/pages team

title: http can't access http
body:
I'm getting a strange protocol must match error. 

`Uncaught SecurityError: Blocked a frame with origin "http://ghbtns.com" from accessing a frame with origin "http://localhost:3000". Protocols, domains, and ports must match.`

This is my iframe code:

```
<iframe src="http://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=jasonshark&repo=oakland-crime-api&type=fork&count=true" allowtransparency="true" frameborder="0" scrolling="0" width="62" height="20"></iframe>
```

How can http not match http? I am running a node.js express server. I'm hoping this isn't a [chrome issue](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17876656/youtube-blocked-a-frame-with-origin-http-www-youtube-com-from-accessing-a-f). Anyone else run into this?

title: Button stays highlighted after mouse is no longer hovering
body:
I have only tried this with the follow button. This happens on both Windows 8.1 and Ubuntu 14.04 machines with the latest version of Chrome.

When I have the mouse over the button, and _slowly_ move it away on the top side, the button remains highlighted blue, even after the mouse is no longer over it. This does not happen when moving the mouse off in any other direction.

body:

I've looked quite a bit but can't find any link for official button. This is ever more surprising for site that advertises itself for "social coding".

title: allowtransparency attribute is not valid HTML5
body:
Validator says:

> The allowtransparency attribute on the iframe element is obsolete. Use CSS instead.

Shall I correct the README examples / templates to use inline:

```
style="background-color: transparent;"
```

instead?

Same for `frameborder` and `scrolling`.

Ah, there is no widely supported alternative to `scrolling` yet: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15494568/html-iframe-disable-scroll

title: Ampersand makes code HTML5 invalid.
body:
In HTML5 ampersands must be escaped via entity `&` inside attributes: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3705591/do-i-encode-ampersands-in-a-href

Is the current state a design choice to make it look nicer, or can I make a PR correcting the readme examples / templates?

title: Download button support for repository releases. If there is no release ...
body: ...download link will be repo link.

title: Buttons do not work in Firefox
body:
Buttons opened in Firefox (tested in 26.0) occasionally point back to this repository regardless of how they're configured.

Inspecting the same HTML document across Chrome and Firefox reveals that the script's source in the `head` tag of the `iframe` is pointing back to the author in Firefox but not in Chrome:

```
<iframe src="http://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=rails&repo=rails&type=watch" allowtransparency="true" frameborder="0" height="20" scrolling="0" width="62">
#document
    <html>
        <head>
            <script src="https://api.github.com/users/mdo?callback=callback"></script>
        </head>
        <body>...</body>
    </html>
</iframe>
```

Any ideas?

title: Fix broken device pixel ratio query for Firefox
body:
#20 is awesome but the correct syntax for device pixel ratio query in FF is `min--moz-device-pixel-ratio` instead of `-moz-min-device-pixel-ratio`. See [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/CSS/Media_queries#-moz-device-pixel-ratio).

Also adds `min-resolution` query, which is stated as the standard way in [CSSWG](http://www.w3.org/blog/CSS/2012/06/14/unprefix-webkit-device-pixel-ratio/).

title: add vertical layout support
body:
Added support for vertical layouts. This means the count is shown above the button in a big bubble, like int the vertical layouts of Twitter/Facebook Like/Google+/Flattr/...

Other minor changes that aren't really part of this feature:
- Added missing `;` on one line.
- Initialize count with ` ` so it does not jump once its get a content.
  Use `String(n)` instead of `n.toString()` out of principle, because it always works (even for `undefined` etc.).
- Run params through `decodeURIComponent` out of principle, even though no parameters values that need escaping should ever occur.

title: HTML fixes
body:
Two small patches that fix HTML issues:
- entities in attributes: `&` becomes `&`
- `px` unit removed from `<iframe>`'s `width` and `height` attributes

With all the love in the world,
@dolmen.

title: Needs ability to make a generic "Download" button
Project URL change breaks people whose site(s) still use Github Pages links
body:
I've noticed tonight, while reviewing the work of a few developers, I was repeatedly confronted with an alert that

"For security reasons, framing is not allowed."

http://cl.ly/image/3L3y3B381o2B

and then am redirected to the 404 page for what used to be the Github Pages URL for this project! 

One such affected project is @stolksdorf's [Parallax JS demo page](http://stolksdorf.github.com/Parallaxjs), so you can head over there (at the moment) to see this redirect in action. (PS, heads up @stolksdorf!)

Though this is obviously something that @github is doing intentionally to avoid people serving framed github pages, in this particular instance it appears to break the websites of anyone who is using github-buttons in their blog or project site, etc, and hasn't yet updated the URL to refer to ghbtns.com.  I'm not sure if the solution here is more evangelism about the URL change, or putting up the old GH pages again, or something else, but I just figured I'd drop in to let you know that at the moment, there are some really averse affects for anyone who uses the project and hasn't updated in the last month.

title: Add "View Source on GitHub" button
body:
Hey there,
This is a really small change. Here's the idea: I'm working on my personal site, and think I'll have audiences that are interested in checking out the code behind a project but aren't super-familiar with github and/or don't want to watch the repository. Since all the "watch" button really does is take a user to a repository's page, I added a 4th type of button with the same functionality whose text instead reads "View Source on GitHub." I think that might make it more friendly to casual audiences. Let me know what you think, and if you like it I'll send the same pull request on gh-pages and update the docs.
-jflinter

title: application/json format.
body:
I've tested the JSON request for my project.

This is my dart client is at
https://github.com/bsjung/start_examples/blob/master/jwt/server/client.dart.

The header is set to {'Content-Type': "application/json"}.
But, the most client software appends to UTF encoding into HTTP header : [application/json; charset=utf-8].

The isMime() loose default is false.
Thus I think the loose default option should be set the true for client software.

-------------------------------------------------------------

 16   bool isMime(String type, {loose: false}) =>
 17       _request.headers[HttpHeaders.contentTypeHeader]
 18           .where((value) => loose ? value.contains(type) : value == type)
 19           .isNotEmpty;

------------------------------------------------------------

Benjamin Jung ( bsjung@gmail.com )

title: Fixed param and payload methods to work with POST requests
body:
Changed "final params" to just "params" inside the `payload` method, so it doesn't create a local variable called `params` instead of using the method variable of the same name.

I think this is the intention of the original code, because otherwise the member variable `params` serves no purpose.

title: Proposed fix for issue #62 to match placeholders with all supported path segment characters per IETF RFC-3986

body: It gives an example of route "/hello/:firstname.:lastname?" and claims it will match "/hello/john" and "/hello/john.doe". While it does match the latter, it is accepting all of 'john.doe' as firstname which is either incorrect or very confusing.

title: Start provides only indirect access to session data
body: Request class of start does not provide direct access to session data. Therefore accessing session data is unnecessary verbose due to the fact that we have to use input property of Request. ``` req.input.session['key'] = 'value'; ``` It would be more efficient to do it this way: ``` req.session['key'] = 'value'; ``` Therefore I propose to introduce the following getter to Request class to overcome unnecessary verbosity. ``` HttpSession get session => _request.session; ```

title: Concept of View is under-documented
body:
A `View` is totally optional, from what I can tell. It's under-documented in the README. Could you either explain what it's used for, and why someone would care, or split the README into the concepts that don't require a View and those that do?

I'm hoping to make Start even easier to learn and use.

Thanks!

title: Return Stream<Socket> from Server#ws().
body: Previously, this returned a Request which didn't match the actual type.

title: Refactor WebSocket Message parsing into an external pub
body:
Clients can't include the Start library as it uses parts of the Dart stdlib not accessable in the web browser. That said, it would be good if there was some common code which allowed WebSocket messages to be consistently serialized and de-serialized between the client and server.

I'm going to work on building this external pub, then including it in the list of Start's dependencies but obviously wanted to hear your thoughts before I started work.

title: Use HttpRequest.uri.queryParameters.
body:
HttpRequest.queryParameters is deprecated. (See
https://groups.google.com/a/dartlang.org/d/msg/misc/Y2UrfSEW6uA/-ZKCV-vLYUcJ)

This is a breaking change, so people not using the newest version of Dart would probably want to hold off on upgrading. Do you want me to iterate the Start version number to indicate this is a breaking change?

title: Add content length, mime type, and update README
Look for index.html as default file in directory
body: Very handle when serving lots of static files.

title: Set MIME type for static files
body: Does start set the right mime type for static files?

title: Add data argument to socket messages
body:
This resolves issue https://github.com/lvivski/start/issues/15, allowing data to optionally be passed to Socket messsage handlers. This also formalizes the concept of a Socket Message.

Also added tests. :)

title: Cookie expiration date weekdays are off by one
body: The `stringifyDate()` method of Cookie (https://github.com/lvivski/start/blob/master/lib/src/cookie.dart#L48) gets the weekday wrong by one, and throws an error if it's Sunday. `DateTime.weekday` returns a value between 1 and 7, but the method assumes it's between 0 and 6.

title: Support the passing of data via websockets
body:
Though being able to "route" Socket messages with the data seems useful, by using the entire contents of the data to do the routing it makes passing data associated with the message impossible.

Some refactorings to address this include:

a) Change the routing to work with JSON data, and look for a specific "msg" and "data" attributes of the parsed hash which would be used for routing and message data respectively.
b) Removing "routing" from the Socket and instead expose the raw data for the application to handle?

Thoughts? I can do a PR.

title: Refactored the way the files are included.
Start runs on the latest dart version now.
body:
- Accounted for the breaking `WebSocket.send()` -> `.add()` rename and
- Dropped the reflection since it has changed (`mirror.namedArguments` is a list of Symbols now, not Strings, which doesn't work with the `NoSuchMethodError` Exception.)
  
  I also dropped the reflection part because of the reasons stated here: #12

title: Why are 'get', 'put', 'post', etc... methods emulated?
body:
Why using noSuchMethod instead of just defining the methods? (https://github.com/lvivski/start/blob/master/lib/server.dart#L40)

(Sorry for flooding you with issues,.. I'm just going through your code and wondering about a few things)

title: Why not using `part of`to include all classes?
body:
I've noticed that you first import `server` which then imports all other parts of `start`, like `response.dart`.

This means that I can't just use the types in my app. Why don't you include all the assets with `part "src/response.dart";`?

title: Class '_HttpResponse' has no instance method 'write'.
body:
A clean install of the example application crashes upon first GET request with an error. No response is returned from the Start HTTP server.

Full error message can be found [in this gist](https://gist.github.com/GreyDev/52d3b53747cf108cc7a4).

Dart Editor also reports:
`"HttpResponse" has no method named "write" - response.dart [Line 60]`
`"HttpResponse" has no method named "write" - response.dart [Line 64]``

As such the example application is broken.

title: The "type 'View' is not loaded" error.
body:
Hi, I am starting to work with Dart.

I try to run the [sample from README](https://github.com/lvivski/start#usage) and get the following message:

```
i:\project\test>dart server.dart
Unhandled exception:
'file:///i:/project/test/server.dart': Error: line 5 pos 19: type 'View' is not loaded
  start(view: new View(), public: 'example/public', port: 3000).then((app) {
                  ^
malformed type used.
#0      main (file:///i:/project/test/server.dart:5:19)
```

I have found the instruction about compilation of the views:

> Don't forget to compile views with bin/compiler.dart (views are precompiled in example).

But it is not clear how to do that. Can you describe the full process of compilation and installation? What should be done to fix this error.

The `pub install start` also does not work in windows, it shows the following message:

```
Could not find a file named "pubspec.yaml" in the directory ....
```

So I have created the following pubspec.yaml file to make it work:

```
name: my_app
dependencies:
    start: any 
```

and then I run the following command:

```
pub install
```

title: translateX, translateY, rotateX, rotateY, etc.
body:
I noticed that in the input example (http://lvivski.com/anima/example/keyboard_mixed.html) you have code to make sure that only one axis is affected at a time:

> a.translate = translate.map(function(t, i) { return t || a.translate[i] })

It's a functionality that I often need when I'm coding for user interaction. It might be nice if that were built into the library so that a user wouldn't have to do it themselves each time they wanted to affect only a single axis. If there was the option to translate, rotate, scale, etc. for each axis (translateX, scaleY, rotateZ, etc.), it could really help.

title: Using `top` instead of `window` to reference requestAnimationFrame, cancelAnimationFrame and performance throws security errors from within an iFrame.
body:
I'm not sure if this is the case for every browser, but this seems to be the case on modern ones. There may be a reason you chose to use `top` instead of `window`, but if your script is running within an iFrame, something about this will throw a cross-domain security error, while using `window` won't.

_(Obviously only if the content of the iFrame is on a different domain as the host.)_

title: fade in animation
CSS animations are broken when the first stylesheet in the page has a @charset declaration
body:
`CSS.prototype.style` tries to insert a keyframe rule at the begining of the first stylesheet. That doesn't work in Chrome (Version 33.0.1750.152 to 36.0.1924.0 canary at least) if the stylesheet has a `@charset` (fails also with `@import`) rule at the very begining (no blank space before). It triggers an `HierarchyRequestError` with the message "Failed to execute 'insertRule' on 'CSSStyleSheet': Failed to insert the rule."

The quick fix is to insert the new keyframes rule at the end of the stylesheet (or at least not at the 0 index) like: `this.stylesheet.insertRule(this.keyframes(animation), this.stylesheet.rules.length);`

title: Ability to call css-defined animations (compatibility with animate.css)
body:
I actually prefer to write animations in css sometimes so it would be handy to be able to use this library to call them. This would allow for a seamless integration with other libraries such as [animate.css](https://github.com/daneden/animate.css) or [magic](https://github.com/miniMAC/magic?source=cc).

An example of this functionality can be found in [move.js](https://github.com/visionmedia/move.js?source=c) with `.animate(..)` which I'm currently using but would like to potentially switch over to this one in the future.

Apologies if this feature already exists but I couldn't find any documentation on it.

Really neat library btw, looking forward to exploring it a little bit further.

Thanks

title: Anima ignores element's current opacity
body:
Adding a new item into a world initializes it's opacity to 1 no matter the current value.

See http://jsfiddle.net/2SpzY/

Setting the opacity in `Item.prototype.init` as `opacity: this.dom.style.opacity` seems to fix it.

title: Add support for additive animations
Add toStart() and toEnd() control methods
body:
I'm not sure if this is possible to do reliably given your approach, but GSAP does this nicely. jQuery did something vaguely similar in the new 1.9 branch, adding a finish() method.

Single animations are easy to do, but what happens when they start overlapping? GSAP which has a great timelining features where you can essentially drop a scrubber into the bottom of the browser window for development and control an animation timeline directly with a draggable scrubber, just like a video program! For serious timeline animations, full-featured development controls are a must...

title: documentation issues
body:
Whoa, this is cool. The "matrix" demo is sweet! Having just completed a pretty complex animation sequence in pure Raphael (which has some painful limitations) the support for "parallel" animation is very appreciated. I want to fool around some more, but here are some initial thoughts. I've broken them into separate issues for ease of reference.

First, about the docs:

1) How about some clarification in the docs on why to choose js versus css worlds, other than client support?

2) How about a browser support chart?

3) Why don't you use semicolons in your demonstration code?  I don't mean to start a debate here, but it really helps make your code accessible, especially to beginners. (At the very least, it's necessary for minification.)

4) A few typos:

"transformationsâ€™ values are relative to the last known Item state, itâ€™s initial state..."

should be

"transformationsâ€™ values are relative to the last known Item state, its initial state..." (no apostrophe)

"You can call .infinite() at the end of you .animateâ€™s chain,"

should be

"You can call .infinite() at the end of  .animateâ€™s chain,"
